isis.stitle: VT 365 Diesel Engine - 2004 Model Year - POWER CYLINDERS - Cleaning and Inspection - Connecting Rod Bearing Fit Check

note.para: Bearing shells must fit tightly in the bore. When bearing shells are inserted into the connecting rod and cap, they protrude above the parting line. This protrusion is required to achieve "bearing crush."

Bearing shells across the open ends are slightly larger than the diameter of the connecting rod bore into which they are assembled. This condition is designed into the bearing shell, causing it to spread outward at the parting line when "bearing crush" load is applied by tightening the bolts. Some snap may be lost in normal use, but bearing replacement is not required because of a nominal loss of snap.
When the assembly is drawn up tight, the bearing is compressed, ensuring positive contact between the backside of the bearing and the bore.

step1.para: Lubricate connecting rod bolts with clean engine oil. Assemble cap to rod with new bearing shells installed. Tighten bolts alternately and evenly to special torque value .
Use a telescoping gauge , measure inside diameter of connecting rod bearing at two locations 90° apart. Average the two inside diameters.
Use a micrometer to measure each crankshaft rod journal diameter.
Subtract the crankshaft rod journal diameter from the respective connecting rod bearing inside diameter to obtain bearing-to-crankshaft running clearance. Repeat for each crankshaft rod journal.
If bearing-to-crankshaft running clearances exceed specifications because of wear on crankshaft, replace or grind crankshaft and install under-size precision type bearing shells.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, grind or replace the crankshaft only. Do not rework bearing cap or bearings; this will reduce running clearance of journal-to-bearing.

note.para: Plastigage® may be used as an alternate method, to determine running clearance.
